revision.comment: /* Rescue of Roger Locher */http→https for [[Google Books]] and [[Google News]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox military person | name = Dale E. Stovall | image = Brig gen dale e stovall.jpg | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1944|02|19}} | death_date = | placeofburial_label = | placeofburial = | birth_place = [[Toppenish, Washington|Toppenish]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]] | death_place = | placeofburial_coordinates = | nickname = | birth_name = | allegiance = {{flag|United States of America}} | branch = [[File:Seal of the US Air Force.svg|25px]] [[United States Air Force]] | serviceyears = 1963-1993 | rank = [[File:US-O7 insignia.svg|20px]] [[Brigadier General (United States)|Brigadier General]] | servicenumber = | unit = | commands = | battles = [[Vietnam War]] | battles_label = | awards = [[Air Force Cross (United States)|Air Force Cross]]
[[Silver Star]] (2)
[[Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)|Distinguished Flying Cross]] (2)
[[Jabara Award]] | relations = | laterwork = }} '''Dale E. Stovall''' (born February 19, 1944) is a retired [[Brigadier General]] in the [[United States Air Force]] who figured prominently in several [[combat search and rescue|search and rescue]] operations during the [[Vietnam War]]. A member of the [[40th Aerospace Rescue and Recovery Squadron]] based in Thailand, on June 2, 1972, he recovered Maj. [[Roger Locher]] from deep inside [[North Vietnam]], the deepest rescue made during the entire Vietnam War. For his efforts in rescuing Locher, Stovall was awarded the [[Air Force Cross (United States)|Air Force Cross]], which described how "he willingly returned to this high threat area, braving intense ground fire, to recover the downed airman from deep in North Vietnam.".{{cite web|url=http://militarytimes.com/citations-medals-awards/recipient.php?recipientid=3468 |title=Capt. Dale Stovall, Air Force Cross|work=Military Times |accessdate=April 7, 2011}} Stovall was also recognized with the 1973 [[Jabara Award]] for Airmanship, two [[Silver Star]] awards and two [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)|Distinguished Flying Cross]] awards for other combat rescues among the 12 successful rescue missions he accomplished during his tour in [[Southeast Asia]].{{cite web |url=http://www.airforcetimes.com/legacy/new/0-AIRPAPER-2642855.php |date=March 1, 2004|title=History in Blue |first=Robert F. |last=Dorr |publisher=Air Force Times |accessdate=April 10, 2011}} Stovall retired from the Air Force as a Brigadier General on June 1, 1993. ==Background== Stovall was born in [[Toppenish, Washington]] and graduated from the [[U.S. Air Force Academy]] at Colorado Springs, Colorado, in the class of 1967. ===Rescue of Roger Locher=== During the initial phase of [[Operation Linebacker]] in May 1972, an American [[McDonnell Douglas F-4 Phantom II|F-4D]] was shot down by a North Vietnamese [[Shenyang J-6]]. Pilot Maj. Robert Lodge refused to [[ejection seat|eject]], but{{cite video|title=John Locher Survival Briefing|url=http://www.f4phantom.com/docs/oyster1b_pt1.mp3 |author=John Locher |accessdate=April 7, 2011}}Davies, Peter ''F-4 Phantom II vs. MiG-21: USAF & VPAF in the Vietnam War'' (Osprey, 2008), p62 his [[Weapon Systems Officer|weapons officer]] [[Roger Locher]] was able to get out of the aircraft. Locher landed, unseen by either friendly or enemy forces, only {{convert|64|km}} from Hanoi, North Vietnam.{{cite journal| url=http://www.airforce-magazine.com/MagazineArchive/Pages/1992/March%201992/0392valor.aspx |title= Valor: A Good Thought to Sleep On |first=John L. |last=Frisbee| publisher=AirforceMagazine.com|volume= 75|number=3|date=March 1992|accessdate=April 6, 2011}} Maj. Locher [[escape and evasion|evaded capture]] and covered over {{convert|19|km}}, gradually losing {{convert|30|lbs}} and his strength.{{cite web|url=http://www.au.af.mil/au/goe/eagle_bios/1986/locher_1986.asp |title=Eagle Biography Roger C. Locher |publisher=Air University, Maxwell-Gunter Air Force Base |location=Montgomery, Alabama |accessdate=April 7, 2011}} On June 1, 1972, his 22nd day behind enemy lines, he was finally able to contact a flight of American jets overhead, calling, "Any U.S. aircraft, if you read Oyster 1 Bravo, come up on Guard".{{cite book |title=Striving for Air Superiority: the Tactical Air Command in Vietnam |first= Craig C. |last=Hannah |page=3 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CEb1sFobGgcC&pg=PA3&dq=roger+locher#v=onepage&q=roger%20locher&f=false}} Lt. James Dunn and others, including [[Richard Stephen Ritchie|Steve Ritchie]] in one of the F-4 aircraft overhead, heard his radio call and remembered Locher's call sign. When the aircraft answered, Locher calmly responded, "Guys I've been down here a long time, any chance of picking me up?"{{cite web|url=http://www.afcent.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123193928 |title='Legends of Aerospace' Visit 'The Rock' |date=March 9, 2010|first=Lindsey |last=Maurice |publisher=386th Air Expeditionary Wing Public Affairs|accessdate=April 7, 2011}} His transmissions left some Americans who did not hear his call in doubt about the authenticity of his message, and they believed that the [[Vietnam People's Army|NVA]] may have manipulated a [[POW]] into impersonating him, setting a trap for the would-be rescuers. ===Rescue operation=== Capt. Stovall, based at [[Nakhon Phanom Royal Thai Navy Base]] in [[Thailand]] responded, piloting a [[Sikorsky MH-53|HH-53]] from the [[40th Aerospace Rescue and Recovery Squadron]] along with a rescue force consisting of several [[Douglas A-1 Skyraider|A-1H]]s and another [[Sikorsky MH-53|HH-53]]. As they neared Locher's position, the A-1 Skyraiders and HH-53C helicopters came under attack from two MiGs, several surface-to-air missiles and gunfire. The rescue force eluded one MiG in a narrow canyon, but were eventually driven back by the enemy fire and failed to get through to Locher on June 1.{{cite web|last1=McGee|first1=Lt. Col. Billy|title=1973 Jabara Award for Airmanship|url=http://jabara.usafalibrary.com/files/6050_FilePath.PDF|accessdate=22 August 2016}} On June 2, 1972, General [[John W. Vogt, Jr.|John Vogt]], commander of the [[Seventh Air Force|7th Air Force]] canceled the entire strike mission set for [[Hanoi]] on that day. He sent a task force of 119 aircraft including Stovall piloting his [[Sikorsky MH-53|HH-53]] rescue helicopter, bombers, and an array of [[McDonnell Douglas F-4 Phantom II|F-4]] escorts, [[Douglas B-66 Destroyer|EB-66]]s, [[Douglas A-1 Skyraider|A-1Hs]], [[Republic F-105 Thunderchief|F105G Weasels]], and [[Boeing KC-135 Stratotanker|KC135]] tankers to get Locher out.{{cite web|url=http://www.pownetwork.org/bios/l/l068.htm |publisher=PowNetwork |title=Lodge, Robert Alfred |accessdate=April 6, 2011}} "We shut down the war to go get Roger Locher," Stovall later said. Capt. Ronald E. Smith in an [[Douglas A-1 Skyraider|A-1H]] guided Capt. Stovall to Locher's position. Only when Locher rose out of the jungle canopy riding the [[forest penetrator|jungle penetrator]] were all of the Americans sure it was him. Despite their proximity to [[Yên Bái Air Base]], no aircraft were lost during Locher's rescue.{{Cite video | people = Steve Ritchie | title = Brig. Gen. Steve Ritchie and the Rescue of Roger Locher | url = http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QvRcP4go-eg | medium = video | publisher = | location = Eustis, Florida | date = Mar 24, 2011 |accessdate=April 7, 2011}} At only 60 miles (97 km) from Hanoi, it was the deepest rescue inside North Vietnam during the Vietnam War. ==Citations== ===Silver Star=== [[File:Silver Star ribbon.svg|thumb|150px|Silver Star ribbon]] Capt Stovall was recognized on several occasions for his bravery during the Vietnam War. He received the [[Silver Star]] for actions on March 2, 1972. The citation reads in part: {{quote|...Captain Stovall with superior airmanship and personal courage, repeatedly volunteered to fly as co-pilot of an HH-53C helicopter into an extremely hostile area in the rescue of a downed airman. While under intense ground fire, Captain Stovall correctly analyzed an in-flight emergency, maintained vital communications with the Search and Rescue forces, insured that all required checks were performed, and was an indispensable aid in assisting the pilot in avoiding hazardous areas...}} Three months later, on June 27, 1972, he was instrumental in recovering another air man for which he was awarded the [[Silver Star]] with Bronze [[Oak Leaf Cluster]]: {{quote|...Captain Stovall, as Aircraft Commander of an HH-53C Rescue Helicopter, voluntarily and at great risk to his own life piloted his aircraft into a hostile and heavily defended area of North Vietnam to effect the rescue of a downed American airman. Realizing the primary recovery aircraft had suffered crippling battle damage, he piloted his aircraft through intense hostile ground fire to complete the rescue of an injured survivor and crewman from encircled ground forces...}} ===Air Force Cross=== [[File:Air Force Cross ribbon.svg|thumb|150px|Air Force Cross]] For his flights on two days deep inside North Vietnam on June 1 and 2, 1972, to rescue Maj. Lochar, Stovall received the [[Air Force Cross (United States)|Air Force Cross]] on November 22, 1972: {{quote|...for extraordinary heroism in military operations against an opposing armed force as an Aircraft Commander of an HH-53C rescue helicopter of the 40th Aerospace Rescue and Recovery Squadron, Nakhon Phanom Royal Thai Air Base, Thailand, in action in Southeast Asia from 1 June 1972 to 2 June 1972. During this period, Captain Stovall, voluntarily and at great risk to his own life, repeatedly penetrated an extremely hostile and heavily defended area to effect the rescue of a downed American airman. Captain Stovall's first attempt to rescue the airman was thwarted by numerous hostile aircraft and missiles being directed at the rescue force. Determined to save this airman, he willingly returned to this high threat area, braving intense ground fire, to recover the downed airman from deep in North Vietnam...}} ===Distinguished Flying Cross=== [[File:Distinguished Flying Cross ribbon.svg|thumb|150px|Distinguished Flying Cross ribbon]] On April 13, 1972, Stovall he assisted in rescuing a Marine pilot for which he received the [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)|Distinguished Flying Cross]]. The citation reads in part: {{quote|...Captain Stovall voluntarily participated in the rescue of a downed Marine pilot from deep within hostile territory. Braving intense anti-aircraft artillery, he defiantly orbited his aircraft for over forty minutes in this extremely hostile area to assist in the successful recovery of the downed pilot.}} Stovall was recognized again six months later on December 6, 1972 and received the Distinguished Flying Cross with Bronze [[Oak Leaf Cluster]]. {{quote|...Captain Stovall's job knowledge, outstanding airmanship, and continuous professionalism, displayed under the constant threat of hostile fire and adverse weather conditions, immeasurably aided in recovery of a downed American airman...}} ===Peace time awards=== [[File:US Defense Superior Service Medal ribbon.svg|thumb|150px|Defense Superior Service Medal ribbon]] [[File:Legion of Merit ribbon.svg|thumb|150px|Legion of Merit ribbon]] During peace time he was recognized with the [[Defense Superior Service Medal]], the [[Legion of Merit]], and the Legion of Merit with Bronze Oak Leaf Cluster. ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==Additional reading== * [http://www.af.mil/AboutUs/Biographies/Display/tabid/225/Article/105509/brigadier-general-dale-e-stovall.aspx Brigadier General Dale E. Stovall] {{DEFAULTSORT:Stovall, Dale E.}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1944 births]] [[Category:United States Air Force generals]] [[Category:American military personnel of the Vietnam War]] [[Category:Recipients of the Legion of Merit]] [[Category:Recipients of the Silver Star]] [[Category:Recipients of the Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)]] [[Category:Recipients of the Air Force Cross (United States)]] [[Category:Recipients of the Defense Superior Service Medal]] [[Category:People from Toppenish, Washington]] [[Category:United States Air Force Academy alumni]] [[Category:Recipients of the Jabara Award]]
